author: de cervantes, miguel
title: Don Quixote
comment: The story of the gentle knight and his servant Sancho Panza has entranced readers for centuries.

author: bunyan, john
title: Pilgrim's Progress
comment: The one with "The Slough of Despond" and "Vanity Fair".

author: swift, jonathan
title: Gulliver's Travels
comment: A wonderful satire that still works for all ages, despite the savagery of Swift's vision.

author: fielding, henry
title: Tom Jones
comment: The adventures of a high-spirited orphan boy: an unbeatable plot and a lot of adventure ending in a blissful marriage.

author: richardson, samuel
title: Clarissa
comment: One of the longest novels in the English language, but unputdownable.

author: sterne, laurence
title: Tristram Shandy
comment: One of the first bestsellers, dismissed by Dr Johnson as too fashionable for its own good.

author: de laclos, pierre choderlos
title: Dangerous Liaisons
comment: An epistolary novel and a handbook for seducers: foppish, French, and ferocious.

author: colville, john
title: The Historie and Life of King James the Sext
comment: Being an account of the affairs of Scotland from the year 1566 to the year 1596; with a short continuation to the year 1617.

author: austen, jane
title: Emma
comment: Near impossible choice between this and "Pride and Prejudice". But Emma never fails to fascinate and annoy.

author: shelley, mary
title: Frankenstein
comment: Inspired by spending too much time with Shelley and Byron.

author: peacock, thomas love
title: Nightmare Abbey
comment: A classic miniature: a brilliant satire on the Romantic novel.

author: de balzac, honore
title: The Black Sheep
comment: Two rivals fight for the love of a femme fatale. Wrongly overlooked.

author: dumas, alexandre
title: The Count of Monte Cristo
comment: A revenge thriller also set in France after Bonaparte: a masterpiece of adventure writing.

author: le guin, ursula kroeber
title: The Left Hand of Darkness
comment: How Le Guin handles a unisex race is one of the amazing parts of the book.
